numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I noticed a pattern about optimism.
2. Younger age groups are typically more optimistic about the direction of the world.
3. This pattern is particularly present in developed countries.
4. The U.S. is a developed country.
5. Japan is a developed country.
6. This pattern is present in the U.S.
7. This pattern is present in Japan.
8. Indonesia seems to be optimistic across all age groups.
9. Indonesia is ahead of the rest of the countries in the graph.
10. I wonder what leads to an optimistic outlook in Indonesia.
11. I ask why all age groups in Indonesia think that the world is getting better with each generation.
12. I also wonder why most people who are 40 years old or older do not think this way.
13. I ask whether this difference is a bias.
14. People who are 40 years old or older are not the new generation.
15. People who are 15 to 24 years old are the new generation.
16. I ask whether people who are 40 years old or older are biased because they are not the new generation.
17. I ask whether people who are 15 to 24 years old are biased because they are the new generation.
18. This topic relates to me and my community.
19. I am part of the new generation.
20. This topic is about my future.
21. This topic is about the state of the world.
22. I will grow up.
23. I will live my life as an adult.
24. World issues will be strongly influenced by the new generation.
25. The economy is a world issue.
26. Healthcare is a world issue.
27. Politics is a world issue.
28. As I grow up, the economy will be strongly influenced by the new generation.
29. As I grow up, healthcare will be strongly influenced by the new generation.
30. As I grow up, politics will be strongly influenced by the new generation.
31. The headline is: New Generations Breed New Hope.
32. I got a clarification from the reveal.
33. Optimism in new generations is based on how people think childhood is changing.
34. Optimism in new generations is based on how people think newer generations grew up.
